questions.text: The gallbladder is capable of distending ... ml:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Normal capacity of the gallbladder is 30–50 ml. Concentration of bile 5-10 times.

questions.text: Sentinel node of gallbladder is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A that is virchow’s node is enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node. Option B that is irish node is enlarged left axillary group of node mostly seen in Ca stomach Option C that is clouquet node is lymph node situated in femoral canal. Option D that is lymph node of lund is a cystic lymph node and it is also a sentinel lymph node of gall bladder.

choices.text: BMI > 30 kg/m' with family history of gallstone

questions.text: Strong risk factor for developing symptomatic gallstones: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Only first-degree relatives of patients with gallstones and obesity (defned as body mass index > 30 Kg/ m2) have been identifed as strong risk factors for development of symptomatic gallstone disease.

questions.text: All of the following are essential for formation of gallstones except (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Three predisposing factors for the formation of gall stone are : Bile stasis, nucleation and lithogenic bile. Crystalization is not important for the gall stone but it is important in the process of formation of urinary stone.

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for gallstones except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Risk Factors for Gallstones Obesity Rapid weight loss Childbearing Multiparity Female sex First-degree relatives Drugs: Ceftriaxone, postmenopausal estrogens, TPN Ethnicity: Native American,, Scandinavian Ileal disease, resection or bypass Increasing age

questions.text: All are true about pigmented stones except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is correct as cholangiohepatitis is one of the predisposing factors for the formation of pigmented CBD stones. Option C Is correct as pigmented stones are primarily formed in the CBD and biliary tree and so they are referred to as a primary CBD stone. Option D is correct as pigmented stones are more common in Asians Secondary CBD stones are the ones which are formed in the gall bladder and come down to CBD due to migration from the gall bladder. As pigmented stones are primarily formed in the biliary tree they are referred to as a primary CBD stone. So Option B is wrong.

choices.text: Associated with disorders of biliary motility and associated bacterial infection
High content of cholesterol and calcium palmitate

questions.text: False about brown pigmented stones: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is correct as pigmented stones are associated with disorders of biliary motility and bacterial infection as they promote bile stasis and nucleation. Option B is wrong as brown pigment stones are more common in Asians and not Caucasians. Option C is correct as brown pigmented stones have soft and earthy consistency, and break easily into smaller fragments. Option D is correct as Brown pigment stones contain calcium bilirubinate, calcium palmitate and calcium stearate as well as cholesterol.

questions.text: Lithogenic bile has the following properties: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bile acids which are present in the bile promote the solubility of the cholesterol and prevent cholesterol stone formation. If the ratio of bile acid to cholesterol reduces in the bile, this is more likely to form a cholesterol stone and such a bile is called as lithogenic bile.

questions.text: Stone formation in gallbladder is enhanced by all expect: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) increased vagal stimulation infact increases the motility of the gall bladder and prevents the gall stone formation rather than promoting the gall stone formation. Options A, B and C are all the risk factors for the formation of the gall stones

questions.text: Gallbladder stone formation is influenced by all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as Clofibrate therapy increases biliary cholesterol. Option B is correct as hyperalimentation decreases GB motility promotes stasis and Gallstone formation. Option C is correct as primary biliary cirrhosis decreases bile salt secretion in bile. Answer is option D as hypercholesterolemia increases chances of atherosclerosis but not GB Stone directly.

questions.text: All are component of Saint's triad except (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A Saints triad consists of Gall stones , Hiatus hernia and Diverticuli in colon so the answer to this question is A as renal stone is not a feature of Saint’s Triad.

questions.text: Commonest type of Gallstone is (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gallstones can be divided into three main types: 1. Cholesterol stones. 2. Pigment (brown/black). 3. mixed stones ( cholesterol and pigment). Most common stones overall:-mixed type

questions.text: Percentage of gallstones which are radio opaque (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Please note only 10 % of gall stones are radio opaque And 90 % of renal stones are radio opaque

questions.text: A Gallstone gets impacted most commonly in which part of common bile duct? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Most gallstones pass out of the body unnoticed, but some become lodged in the common bile duct, causing jaundice. A frequent site of gallstone impaction is the ampulla of Vater, where the common channel meets the small intestine. Blockage of the common channel by a gallstone can induce acute pancreatitis.

questions.text: The predominant constituent of the pale yellow gallstones in the gallbladder is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cholesterol or mixed stones contain 51–99 percent pure cholesterol plus an admixture of calcium salts, bile acids, bile pigments and phospholipids. • When bile is supersaturated with cholesterol or bile acid concentrations are low, unstable unilamellar phospholipid vesicles form, from which cholesterol crystals may nucleate, and stones may form. • Cholestrol stones are solitaire in shape and yellow in colour. • Cholesterol stones are usually solitary.

questions.text: Most common type of gallstone in India is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) MC gallstone overall: Mixed (90%) MC gallstones in USA and Europe: Cholesterol stones (Mixed, if given in the option) MC gallstones in India (Asia): Pigment stones (80%)

questions.text: By definition pigment stone contain how much % of cholesterol (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pigment stone is the name used for stones containing less than 30% cholesterol.

questions.text: Investigation of choice in acute cholecystitis (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) IOC for acute cholecystitis: USG Gold standard for diagnosis of acute cholecystitis: HIDA scan USG is IOC for acute calculous cholecystitis, chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis

questions.text: Seagull sign is seen in: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MERCEDES BENZ SIGN OR SEAGULL SIGN The centre of Gallstone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure, this gives rise to characteristic dark shapes on radiograph,known as the Mercedes Benz sign or Seagull sign.

questions.text: The substance used in OCG is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Iopanoic acid is used in oral cholecystography(OCG). Biligraffin is used in IV cholangiography. OCG:- An x-ray procedure for diagnosing gallstones. The patient takes iodine-containing tablets by mouth for one night or two nights in a row. The iodine is absorbed from the intestine into the bloodstream, removed from the blood by the liver, and excreted by the liver into the bile. The iodine, together with the bile, is highly concentrated in the gallbladder

questions.text: Investigation of choice in suspected gallbladder stone is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) USG is IOC for acute calculous cholecystitis, chronic cholecystitis and cholilithiasis. Option B is wrong as X-rays are rarely helpful in gall stone disease as 90 % of gall stones are radiolucent. Option C that is barium is not used for gall stones, it is used for GI pathologies. Option D that is oral cholycystography was once the preferred investigation but with the advances and easy availability of USG, USG has become the investigation of choice for gall stones.

questions.text: Not a complication of gallstones: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Effects and Complications of gall stones.

choices.text: Acute cholecystitis presents with GB perforation
Acute cholecystitis presents with mucosal ulceration of GB
Mucocele of GB contains infected bile

questions.text: True about Gallstone disease: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is wrong as most common symptom of acute cholycystitis is right upper quadrant pain of much longer duration than biliary colic. Option C is wrong as most of the gall stones are asymptomatic . Option D is wrong as mucocele of gall bladder does not contain infected bile, it has mucous collected in the gall bladder . Option B is the answer to this question as in acute cholycystitis due to inflammation and distension of the gall bladder one can develop an ulceration of the mucosa.

questions.text: Gallstones may be complicated by which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B, & C)

questions.text: Ursodeoxycholic acid is a: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Medical therapy for gallstones utilizes bile acids: Chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) and Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) • They inhibit HMG-CoA reductase, the rate limiting enzyme for cholesterol synthesis, thus decreases cholesterol saturation of bile Prerequisites for medical therapy Radiolucent (cholesterol) stones Stones <15 mm in diameter Functioning GB No acute symptoms Drawbacks of medical treatment Low rates of complete resolution High recurrence rate Not cost-effective (expensive drug has to be taken for up to 2 years) Need of maintenance therapy to prevent recurrence

questions.text: In which condition, medical treatment of Gallstone is indicated? (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prerequisites for medical therapy Radiolucent (cholesterol) stones Stones <15 mm in diameter Functioning GB Non-acute symptoms

choices.text: Mixed stones are common in the Asians
In Saint's triad diverticulosis of colon and hiatus hernia coexist
Is a risk factor in the development of GB carcinoma
A mucocele of GB is caused by a stone impacted in the Hartmann's pouch

questions.text: Regarding stones in gallbladder the following are true except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) majority of the gall bladder stones are radiolucent and not radio opaque. Only 10% of all the gall stones are radio opaque. Option A is correct as mixed stones are more common in Ascians and cholesterol stones are more common in western countries . Option B is correct as Saint’s triad consists of GB stone + diverticuli of colon + hiatus hernia. Option C is true as chronically presence of gall stones predisposes to development of GB Carcinoma. Option E is correct as mucocele of gall bladder is formed due to impaction of stone in hartmann`s pouch .

questions.text: In Gallstone ileus, obstruction is seen at: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gall Stone Ileus in a condition in which passage of a stone occurs through a spontaneous biliary-enteric fistula leading to a mechanical bowel obstruction. The most common site of obstruction in this condition is part of intestine just proximal to ileocaecal junction.

choices.text: May be diagnosed with abdominal X-ray
Most common fistula is to duodenum
Cholecystectomy should be done in same episode

questions.text: All are true about Gallstone ileus except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is the answer in this question because Most patients in Gallstone ileus are unstable to withstand a prolonged operative procedure, so cholecystectomy should not be done in same episode.Fistula can be addressed at a second laparotomy. Option A is correct as X ray will tell you the signs of small bowel obstruction along with air in the biliary tree which is suggestive of gall stone ileus. Option B is correct as the most common site of fistulous communication in gall stone ileus is between gall bladder and duodenum. Second most common site of fistulous communication is between gall bladder and transverse colon. Option C is also correct as the cause of obstruction is the gall stone which has entered the bowel from the gall bladder and this site of obstruction can change depending on the position of the stone in the small bowel. So this kind of obstruction is called a tumbling obstruction.

questions.text: Most common site of fistula in Gallstone ileus is between: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Passage of a stone through a spontaneous biliary-enteric fistula leading to a mechanical bowel obstruction MC site of fistula: Between the gallbladder and duodenum 2nd MC site: Between gallbladder and transverse colon

questions.text: Riggler's triad consists of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C) Riggler's triad is a combination of findings on an abdominal radiograph of people with gallstone ileus, a condition where a large gallstone causes bowel obstruction. Riggler's triad consists of: (1) small bowel obstruction, (2) a gallstone outside the gallbladder, and (3) air in the bile ducts.

questions.text: The most common site of intestinal obstruction in gallstone ileus is: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gall Stone Ileus in a condition in which passage of a stone occurs through a spontaneous biliary-enteric fistula leading to a mechanical bowel obstruction. The most common site of obstruction in this condition is part of intestine just proximal to ileocaecal junction. Duodenal obstruction due to gallstones, usually in the bulb is known as Bouveret’s syndrome. It is treated by duodenostomy or pyloroplasty. Duodenum is the least common site of obstruction in gall stone ileus.

choices.text: Cholecystectomy, closure of fistula and removal of stone by enterotomy

questions.text: The treatment of Gallstone ileus is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) It is a surgical emergency without a period of waiting in the hope that stone will pass. In case of obstruction in the ileum calculus can be manipulated proximally to a healthy jejunum where a safe enterotomy and stone removal may be executed. Stable patients: Take down of the biliary-enteric fistula and cholecystectomy during the same procedure is warranted because recurrent cholecystitis and cholangitis are common. Unstable patients or a significant inflammation in RUQ: Unstable to withstand a prolonged operative procedure, the fistula can be addressed at a second laparotomy.

questions.text: The treatment of choice for a mucocele of gallbladder is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Due to obstruction of cystic duct by stone in the neck (Hartmann's pouch) without any infection or inflammation,mucocele is formed. • Gallbladder distended over a period of time by mucus (Mucocele) or by a clear transudate (Hydrops) • Patients usually remains asymptomatic but chronic RUQ pain may be there Clinical features: • Visible, Easily palpable, soft, non-tender mass in right hypochondrium • Dyspepsia • Investigation: USG, LFT Treatment: Cholecystectomy

choices.text: Distended GB is seen in scintigraphy

questions.text: All are true about acute acalculous cholecystitis except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer in this case as Ultrasonography is the diagnostic test of choice for acalculous cholecystitis especially because it can be done at the bedside, and on Cholescintigraphy demonstrates absent gallbladder filling and not the distended gall bladder . Option B is correct as Visceral ischemia is common in acute acalculous cholecystitis and may explain the high incidence of GB gangrene. Option C is correct as acalculous cholecystitis is more common in elderly and critically ill patients after trauma, in burns patients, in patients with long-term TPN and those who have undergone major operations (abdominal aneurysm repair and cardiopulmonary bypass) Option D is correct as in acalculous cholecystitis there is acute inflammation of gallbladder without stones. It has a more fulminant course than the acute calculous cholecystitis.

questions.text: Acalculous cholecystitis are caused by: A. DM B. TPN C. Leptospirosis D. Estrogen therapy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B,C) A,B and C are Causes of acalculous cholycystitis

choices.text: Manifestation of disturbed microcirculation in critically ill patient
Prolonged parenteral nutrition can be causative

questions.text: Which of the following statements about acalculous cholecystitis is incorrect? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option D is wrong as the preferred treatment in acalculous cholycystitis is emergency cholecystectomy for stable patients Because of high incidence of gangrene, perforation and empyema, open cholecystectomy is often the preferred approach. Option A is correct as vascular ischemia to the gall bladder in critically ill patients is an important cause of acalculous cholecystitis. Option B is also correct as prolonged TPN is an important cause of acalculous cholecystitis Option C is correct as acalculous cholecystitis follows a more fulminant course than the acute calculous cholecystitis and it commonly progresses to gangrene, empyema, or perforation.

questions.text: Indications of prophylactic cholecystectomy are all except: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Indications of prophylactic cholecystectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for cholecystectomy? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer because just the presence of multiple polyps is not an indication of cholecystectomy. Option A that is GB polyp with stone, Option B that is GB polyp > 1 cm even if asympotomatic and all the symptomatic GB polyps are the definite indications of cholecystectomy.

questions.text: The indications of cholecystectomy are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B,E) Option B that is mucocele of gall bladder and option E that is symptomatic cholelithiasis are definitive indications of cholecystectomy . Option A that is strawberry gall bladder is not an indication of cholecystectomy. Option C Just the presence of GB polyp is not an indication of cholycystectomy, if we have GB polyp with gall stone, or GB polyp >1 cm in size or sympotomatic GB Polyp then this becomes an indication of cholecystectomy. Option D is wrong as asymptomatic gall stone is not an indication of cholecystectomy, if we have a symptomatic gall stone then only we go for cholecystectomy.

questions.text: The technique of laparoscopic cholecystectomy was first described by? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HISTORY OF LAPAROSCOPIC CHOLECYSTECTOMY Dr.Kurt Semm, the father of “pelviscopy,” performed the first laparoscopic appendectomy in 1980. Eric Muhe performed the first laparoscopic cholecystectomy in 1982. He used a modified operating laparoscope placed at the umbilicus after establishing pneumoperitoneum. In 1987, Phillipe Mouret performed the first video laparoscopic cholecystectomy by using a camera atached to the laparoscope.

questions.text: All are indications for cholecystectomy except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A that is emphysematous choleecystitis is caused by clostridium and it is a surgical emergency to be performed as soon as possible to prevent perforation of gall bladder . Option B that is biliary dyskinesia is an important indication of cholycystectomy. Option C that is perforation of gall bladder is a surgical emergency and needs emergency cholycystectomy as soon as possible. Option D that is adenomyomatosis, just the presence of adenomyomatosis is not an indication of cholycystectomy. It is indicated in symptomatic adenomyomatosis or when cholelithiasis is present.

questions.text: After surgery, there was 50 ml bile output from abdominal drain on 1st post-operative day. Management is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A small amount of biliary drainage following cholecystectomy should cause no alarm because it usually disappears within 1 or 2 days. However, excessive biliary drainage through the wound or drain site, jaundice, sepsis or a combination of these events early in the post-operative period should suggest a bile duct injury, as should copious biliary drainage for more than few post-op days.

questions.text: Which of the following is the absolute contraindication for laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Absolute contraindication for laparoscopic cholecystectomy is : Unable to tolerate general anaesthesia Refractory coagulopathy Suspicion of carcinoma Relative contraindication for cholecystectomy is : Previous upper abdominal surgery Cholangitis Diffuse peritonitis Cirrhosis or portal hypertension Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Cholecystoenteric fistula Morbid obesity Pregnancy

questions.text: A 45-years old female presents with symptoms of acute cholecystitis. On USG there is a solitary gallstone of size 1.5 cm. Symptoms are controlled with medical management. Which of the following is the next most appropriate step in the management of this patient? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) TREATMENT OF ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS • Early cholecystectomy performed within 2 to 3 days (within 72 hours) of presentation is preferred over interval or delayed cholecystectomy that is performed 6 to 12 weeks after initial medical therapy. • Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred approach to patients with acute cholecystitis.

questions.text: Antegrade cholecystectomy: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Types of Cholecystectomy Retrograde: Hilar structure dissection occurs first, followed by the removal of gallbladder in the triangle of Calot’s Antegrade or Fundus first or Top Down: Separates GB from the liver before the cystic duct and artery are ligated. Considered safer because it allows for the progressive demonstration of the anatomy down to the infundibulocystic junction.

choices.text: ERCP and removal of gallbladder stones

questions.text: A 69-years old male patient having coronary artery disease was found to have gallbladder stones while undergoing a routine ultrasound of the abdomen. There was no history of biliary colic or jaundice at any time. What is the best treatment advice for such a patient for his gallbladder stones? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) There was no clear cost benefit and no life-years were gained from prophylactic cholecystectomy, indicating no clear-cut advantages of prophylactic cholecystectomy in asymptomatic cholelithiasis. As a result, in patients with asymptomatic gallstones, expectant management is recommended.

questions.text: Features of healthy gallbladder on laparotomy are:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A,B) HEALTHY GALLBLADDER • Greenish blue or sea green colour • Thin and elastic wall • Can be emptied by squeezing

questions.text: Most common malignancy after cholecystectomy is of: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bile acids can induce hyperproliferation of the intestinal mucosa via a number of intracellular mechanisms. Cholecystectomy, which alters the enterohepatic cycle of bile acids, has been associated with a moderately increased risk of proximal colon cancers. . A number of cofactors have been identified that may enhance or neutralize the carcinogenic effects of bile acids, e.g. the amount of dietary fat, fiber, or calcium. Calcium, in fact, binds bile acids and thus may reduce their negative impact.

choices.text: Decreased incidence of bile duct injuries

questions.text: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is largely preferred for all of the following reasons to conventional laparotomy except:(LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) BILE DUCT INJURY • Most commonly during laparoscopic cholecystectomy • Incidence of bile duct injury during open cholecystectomy is 0.1- 0.2% • Incidence of bile duct injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy is 0.3-0.85%

choices.text: ERCP + choledocholithotomy followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Laparoscopic cholecystectomy followed by ERCP + choledocholithotomy.

questions.text: A 50-years old with history of jaundice in the past has presented with right upper quadrant abdominal pain. Examination and investigations reveal chronic calculous cholecystitis. The liver functions tests are with in normal limits and on ultrasound examination, the common bile ducts is not dilated. Which of the following will be the procedure of choice in her? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is the answer In the given question as there was an episode of jaundice, but at present, LFT is normal and CBD is not dilated. The best option is laparoscopic cholecystectomy only. Option B is the answer when while performing a laparoscopic cholycystectomy surgeon finds a CBD stone and he is not experienced to perform a laparoscopic CBD exploration so he needs to convert the procedure to an open cholecystectomy with CBD explorartion. Option C is the answer when patient has been diagnosed with CBD stone preoperatively and so we subject the patient to preop ERCP then laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Option D is the answer when after performing laparoscopic cholecystectomy we see a retained stone in the CBD so we perform postop ERCP to remove the stone.

questions.text: A 88-year male patient presented with end stage renal disease with coronary artery block and metastasis in the lungs. Now presents with acute cholecystitis, patient's relatives wants you to do something: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) If patients are unfIt for surgery, percutaneous, ultrasound guided, or CT guided cholecystostomy is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: An otherwise normal female presents with symptoms of flatulent dyspepsia. She was started on proton pump inhibitors, which controlled her symptoms. The next step in management of this condition should be: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) FLATULENT DYSPEPSIA •Flatulent dyspepsia is usually described as symptom of Gallstone disease. •However, flatulent dyspepsia (in an otherwise normal female), that responds to PPI is more likely to result from reflux or peptic ulcer disease (rather than Gallstone disease) and does not require surgical management or invasive investigations for gallbladder disease. •Patients with these symptoms should be observed (wait and watch) or investigated by endoscopy to exclude reflux or peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: In cholecystectomy, fresh plasma should be given:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) FRESH FROZEN PLASMA:- • Transfusions with FFP are given to replenish clotting factors. • The effectiveness of the transfusion in maintaining haemostasis is dependent on the quantity of each factor delivered and its half-life. • The half-life oF the most stable clotting factor, factor VII, is 4 to 6 hours. • A reasonable transfusion scheme would be to give FFP on call to the operating room. • This way the transfusion is complete prior to the incision, with circulating factors to cover the operative and immediate postoperative period.

questions.text: All of the following statements about xanthogranulomatous inflammation are true except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as xanthogranulomatous cholycystitis is an Inflammatory disease characterized by a focal or diffuse destructive inflammatory process with lipid-laden macrophages. These ccells are referred to as a foamy cells. Option B is correct as there is presence of yellowish hypoechoic nodules or bands in thickened GB wall together with calculi (cholesterol or mixed gallstones) in patient of chronic disease. Option C is correct as in Xanthogranulomatous Cholecystitis there is presence of multinucleated giant cells. Option D is wrong as xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis is not associated with tuberculosis in any ways.

questions.text: Acute emphysematous cholecystitis is caused by: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Emphysematous cholecystitis is caused by clostridium Emphysematous pyelonephritis is caused by E.coli Xanthogranulomatous cholycystitis is not an infective condition. it is basically caused because of the rupture of the rokitansky ashoff sinuses. Xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is caused by proteus .

choices.text: Disease of defective metabolism of choline
Concerned with epithelial tumors of brain
Diffuse deposition of cholesterol in mucosa of gallbladder

questions.text: Cholesterosis is (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cholesterosis is also called as strawberry gall bladder. It is an acquired histologic abnormality of the gallbladder epithelium that results in an excessive accumulation of lipid (cholesterol esters and triglyceride) within epithelial macrophage of the GB wall. Cholesterol stones are found in half of the cases.

questions.text: Indications of cholecystectomy in GB polyp removal are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer because just the presence of multiple polyps is not an indication of cholecystectomy. Option B that is GB polyp with stone, Option A that is GB polyp > 1 cm even if asympotomatic and all the symptomatic GB polyps are the definite indications of cholecystectomy.

questions.text: Risk factors associated with malignancy in GB polyp are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Risk factors associated with malignancy: Age > 60 years Coexistence of gallstones Documented increase in size Size > 10 mm

choices.text: Symptomatic polyps are indication for cholecystectomy
Polyp with stone is an increased risk of malignancy

questions.text: False about GB polyps: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is wrong because Adenomyomatosis appears as a sessile polyp with characteristic microcysts on USG and is often >10 mm in size . Option B is correct because cholesterol polyps are the most common type, they are usually <10 mm in size. Have a characteristic echogenic pedunculated appearance on USG and are multiple in 30% of cases. Option C is correct as symptomatic GB polyp is an indication of cholecystectomy. Option D is also correct as GB polyp with stone increases the chance of malignancy.

questions.text: On abdominal ultrasound gallbladder shows diffuse wall thickening with hyperechoic nodules at neck and comet tail artifacts. The most likely diagnosis will be: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) GALLBLADDER ADENOMYOMATOSIS Adenomyomatosis is a benign condition characterized by hyperplastic changes of unknown etiology involving the GB wall. It causes overgrowth of mucosa, thickening of muscular wall, and formation of intramural diverticula or sinus tracts termed as Aschoff-Rokitansky sinuses. These sinuses may contain cholesterol crystals. The disease can be focal or diffuse. It has no malignant potential. Diagnosis USG: The presence of cholesterol crystals in these sinuses can result in “diamond ring sign”, “V-shaped”, or “comet-tail” artifacts on USG. Adenomyomatosis appears as a sessile polyp with characteristic microcysts on USG and is often >10 mm. Cholecystography is more specific for diagnosis. Treatment Cholecystectomy is indicated in symptomatic adenomyomatosis or when cholelithiasis is present.

questions.text: The association of Cholelithiasis with CA Gall Bladder is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cholelithiasis is seen in 75-98% of all patients with CA Gall Bladder. The incidence of CA GB in a population of patients with gallstones is from 0.3-3%.

questions.text: Precancerous lesions of GB are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Risk Factors for Carcinoma Gallbladder Gallstones >3 cm Porcelain gallbladder Anomalous pancreatobiliary junction Choledochal cysts Adenomatous polyps Primary sclerosing cholangitis Obesity Salmonella typhi Infection

questions.text: Organism associated with fish consumption and also causes carcinoma gallbladder: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) • Clonorchis sinensis is a liver fuke, acquired by ingestion of raw or inadequately cooked fresh water fishes. • In human body, it lives within bile ducts and causes infammatory reaction leading to cholangiohepatitis and biliary obstruction. • It is a well known risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma. • It is a rare, but mentioned risk factor for carcinoma gallbladder

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for carcinoma gallbladder, except: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Risk Factors for Carcinoma Gallbladder Gallstones >3 cm Porcelain gallbladder Anomalous pancreatobiliary junction Choledochal cysts Adenomatous polyps Primary sclerosing cholangitis Obesity Salmonella typhi Infection

questions.text: In a male after laparoscopic cholecystectomy, specimen is sent for histopathology which shows carcinoma gallbladder stage T1a. Appropriate management is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Management of Gall Bladder Ca : T1a : Cholecystectomy is enough T1b with negative margins and no lymphovascular invasion : Cholecystectomy is enough T1b with positive margin +/- lymphovascular invasion : Extended cholecystectomy

questions.text: Survival in unresectable GB carcinoma is? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Median survival for patients presenting with unresectable disease is 2-4 months with 1-year survival is less than 5%. • Goal of palliation is to relieve jaundice, pain, bowel obstruction and prolongation of life. • Percutaneous stents are effective for relieving jaundice and should be used, as expected survival does not usually warrants a surgical bypass. • Gemcitabine plus cisplatin (Reference regimen) is used for palliation of unresectable disease.

questions.text: T2N1 of CA GB represents which stage?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T1b, T2, T3 tumour with no evidence of metastasis: Re-resection, extended cholecystectomy (possible CBD or extended hepatic resection) Extended cholecystectomy consists of cholecystectomy with en-bloc resection of segments IVB and V; including lymphadenectomy of the cystic duct, pericholedochal, periportal, and posterior pancreaticoduodenal and local interaortocaval lymph nodes

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adenocarcinoma is the MC histologic subtype of Carcinoma Gall Bladder.

questions.text: Choledochal cyst in intrahepatic biliary tree: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Let us first have a look at Todani or Alonso Lej classification for choledochal cyst Type I: Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type Ia: cystic dilation Type Ib: focal segmental dilation Type Ic: fusiform dilation Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele) Type IVA: Dilation of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts (Caroli’s disease) As the asking about the choledochal cyst involving intra hepatic biliary tree answer is IVa as in this there is involvement of both extra plus intra hepatic biliary tree.

questions.text: Caroli's disease is: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Let us first have a look at Todani or Alonso Lej classification for choledochal cyst Type I: Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type Ia: cystic dilation Type Ib: focal segmental dilation Type Ic: fusiform dilation Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele) Type IVA: Dilation of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts (Caroli’s disease)

questions.text: Central dot sign is seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Central dot sign is basically a CT Scan finding seen in Type V choledochal cyst or caroli’s disease. It represents portal vein radicals which is seen after enhancement within dilated intra-hepatic bile ducts and appears as a central dot in the cyst. In Focal Nodular Hyperplasia we do not see a central dot sign , what we see in FNH on CT Scan is a central stellate scar. Hemangioma can be diagnosed on CT scan by delayed washout of contrast from hemangioma.

questions.text: Most commonly seen choledochal cyst: (PGI May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Most common type of choledochal cyst is Type I Order of frequency of choledochal cyst is Type I > Type IV > Type III Let us first have a look at Todani or Alonso Lej classification for choledochal cyst Type I: Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type Ia: cystic dilation Type Ib: focal segmental dilation Type Ic: fusiform dilation Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct (choledochocele) Type IVA: Dilation of the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts (Caroli’s disease)

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for choledochal cyst? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) One of the most important complication of choledochal cyst is malignancy and the risk of malignancy persists till the mucosa lining the cyst and cyst wall in present in the body. Excision of the cyst helps us get rid of the mucosa lining the cyst and the cyst wall and thus reduces the chance of occurrence of cholangiocarcinoma. So Excision of cyst is the treatment of choice for choledochal cyst. Options B,C and D can provide the pathway for adequate drainage of the cyst but the risk of carcinoma still persists as the cyst wall is not removed . So they are not preferred treatment options.

questions.text: Reconstructive surgery for choledochal cyst is not done in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Understand the fact that treatment of choice for choledochal cyst is excision of the cyst. After excision of choledochal cyst you need to establish the continuity of the biliary tract for the drainage of the biliary secretions and bile and for stablishing this you need to perform some or the other reconstructive procedure like choledochojejunostomy . Type III Choledochal cyst is a unique entity and is described as a cystic dilation of the terminal part of the bile duct. Treatment of Type III choledochal cyst is endoscopic sphincterotomy with cystic unroofing and as after this procedure there is no need to reconstruct the biliary system in order to establish continuity

choices.text: Resection decreases the incidence of malignancy but risk persists

questions.text: Choledochal cyst: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Treatment of choice for choledochal cyst is excision of the cyst and after excision of the cyst there is decrease in the incidence of occurrence of cholangiocarcinoma but the risk still persists. Occurance of gall stones is one of the complications of choledochal cyst but it does not occur in 80 % of cases. It is less common . Treatment of choledochal cyst is excision of the cyst and not Roux-en-Y cystojejunostomy. Roux-en-Y-cystojejunostomy is needed for the reconstruction after the excision of the cyst. Type IV choledochal cyst is not the most common type, Type I is the most common type.

questions.text: A 10 years female presents with pain in the right hypochondrium, fever, jaundice and a palpable mass in the right hypochondrium the probable diagnosis is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) In this question we have a patient who has pain in right hypochondrium, fever, jaundice and a palable mass. This classic triad of pain, intermittent jaundice and palpable mass is present in 10 % of patients of choledochal cyst. Option A is not the answer as hepatitis has pain in right hypochondrium but it does not have a palpable mass, patients can have hepatomegaly. Option B that is hepatoma can present as a painless palpable mass but jaundice is not a common feature in hepatoma. Option D that is mucocele of gall bladder can present as palpable mass of gall bladder but presence of jaundice is not a feature of this.

questions.text: A 60 yrs old man presents with jaundice & intense pruritus since last 4 weeks. Patient also complains of pale stools & some weight loss. On examination the patient is icteric with scratch marks present all over the body. Abdominal examination reveals a smooth globular mass moving with respiration in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. The most probable diagnosis in this patient is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) A distended gall bladder will not be palpable in patient with hilar cholangioca. As per courvosier’s law ,GB will not be palpable in choledocholithiasis. Ca head of the pancreas/ Periampullary ca classically presents as obstructive jaundice with smooth palapable GB

questions.text: A 49-years-old woman comes to the emergency department because of right upper-quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, and fever. She also complains of pain in her right shoulder. A right upper quadrant ultrasound reveals multiple gallstones and pericholecystic fluid. Which of the following dermatomes is most likely involved in her shoulder pain?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Pain in the liver and gallbladder can be referred to C3-C5 dermatomes of the right shoulder due to irritation of diaphragm which is supplied by phrenic nerve (C3-5). Many people are familiar with the projection of cardiac pain to the left shoulder, which is a similar phenomenon. Pancreatic disease can also produce left shoulder pain. On physical examination, referred pain can usually be distinguished from pain truly originating in the perceived area by palpation and manipulation of the area. Local physical manipulation does not usually alter the character or intensity of referred pain, but it does alter those features of skin, joint, or muscle pain truly localized to the region.

questions.text: The gallbladder of a 51-year-old female patient is characterized by the presence of multiple gallstones, consistent with the diagnosis of cholecystitis. Which of the following tests would be anticipated to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A positive Murphy’s sign is indicative of gallbladder inflammation. ask the patient to take a deep breath while you palpate just below the right costal margin. With inspiration, the gallbladder moves downwards, and if it is inflamed the resulting contact with your hand will cause pain and the patient will generally hold their breath. A positive test requires a negative result when the test is repeated on the left.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man is admitted to the emergency department complaining of cramping midabdominal pain, abdominal distention, and vomiting for the past 24 hours. History reveals that the patient suffers from gallstones. Abdominal radiograph reveals air in the gallbladder and biliary tree. In which of the following sites is a gallstone most likely lodged?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The patient in the above scenario has mechanical bowel obstruction due to gall stone(gall stone ileus) which gets impacted at the ileocaecal junction. The stone enters the small bowel after a fistula formation with the duodenum. This explains the presence of air in the biliary tree.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the emergency department complaining of persistent severe right upper quadrant pain for the past 2 hours. During that period of time he felt nauseated, was sweating profusely, and also experienced pain in the posterior aspect of his right shoulder and upper back. The pain began shortly after a lunch consisting of “fast food.” Ultrasound examination reveals multiple stones in an inflamed gallbladder with a normal bile duct. Which of the following spinal nerve segments are involved in the shoulder pain, associated with cholecystitis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Referred pain from cholecystitis is generally referred to the region of the inferior angle of the right scapula. These fibers are generally from T5 to T9. These sensory fibers for pain are stimulated by the gallbladder inflammation because of the proximity of the adjacent structures. C3 to C5 sensory fibers innervate the shoulder area.

choices.text: The primary bile acids are deoxycholic and lithocholic acid.
The primary phospholipid in bile is lecithin.
Brown pigmented gallstones are more likely to be found in the gallbladder versus the CBD

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding bile and gallstones?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Normally, more than 95% of bile salts are reabsorbed by the enterohepatic circulation and negative feedback accounts for replacement of the 0.5 g loss of bile salts in the stool. The primary bile acids are cholic acid and chenodeoxycholic acid. The secondary bile acids are lithocholate and deoxycholate acids. Cholecystectomy has minimal effect on bile acid secretion but does increase enterohepatic circulation of bile salts. Brown pigment gallstones occur more commonly in the setting of biliary stasis such as cholangitis and tend to form in the CBD. Black pigment stones are associated with hemolytic disorders and are more likely to be found within the gallbladder

questions.text: A subtotal gastrectomy with D2 dissection performed for Stage 3 gastric adenocarcinoma in the antrum includes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Generally, the surgeon strives for a grossly negative margin of at least 5 cm. More than 15 resected lymph nodes are required for adequate staging, even in the low-risk patient. In the absence of involvement by direct extension, the spleen and pancreatic tail are not removed. Reconstruction is usually by Billroth-I gastrojejunostomy or Roux-en-Y reconstruction.

questions.text: Hydrops of the gallbladder
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) When a gallstone becomes impacted in the cystic duct, the typical course is that acute cholecystitis will develop in the patient. Less frequently, an acute infection does not develop in the patient even though the cystic duct remains obstructed. In this situation, bile within the gallbladder becomes absorbed, but the gallbladder epithelium continues to secrete glycoprotein(mucus). The gallbladder becomes distended with mucinous material. This is known as hydrops. The gallbladder may be palpable but does not create the Murphy sign.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female underwent an uneventful laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Two weeks later she presents to the emergency department with vague abdominal pain. Her vitals are normal and stable. Total bilirubin is 1.1 mg/dL. CT scan demonstrates a large bilioma. Which of the following is the best choice for definitive intervention?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The most commonly identified culprit is a cystic duct stump leak likely secondary to an improperly placed surgical clip. When patients present with a bilioma, they should be managed quickly because this can lead to severe morbidity and mortality secondary to biliary sepsis. Management should begin with ERCP, biliary stent placement, and sphincterotomy to promote internal biliary drainage by decreasing resistance in the biliary tree. CT-guided drainage may be considered as the first step in management in critically ill patients to gain quick control of the septic source, but it will not address the underlying cause.

questions.text: The arterial supply of the common bile duct is derived from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The majority of the blood flow to the human common bile duct originates from the right hepatic artery and gastroduodenal arteries, with major trunks running along the medial and lateral aspects of the common duct (often referred to as the 3 o’clock and 9 o’clock positions).

choices.text: Cyst resection and primary re-anastomosis of the common bile duct.
Resection of the common bile duct, cholecystectomy, and hepatico-jejunostomy
Resection of the cyst and choledocho-duodenostomy

questions.text: A 22 years old female patient presents with pain abdomen, jaundice. MRCP was done which is shown below. What is the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Choledochal cysts are rare congenital cystic dilations of the extrahepatic and/or intrahepatic biliary tree. Females are affected three to eight times more commonly than men. The most common presentations in adulthood are jaundice and cholangitis, and less than one-half of patients present with the classic clinical triad o abdominal pain, jaundice, and a mass. A definitive imaging technique such as endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP), percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography, or magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is required to assess the biliary anatomy and plan the appropriate surgical treatment. The risk of cancer development in these patients is up to 15%, and can largely be mitigated by excision o the biliary tree. Types I, II, and IV cysts are treated with excision o the extrahepatic biliary tree with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy. Type IV may also require a segmental liver resection. Sphincterotomy is recommended or type III cysts.

questions.text: Risk factors for acalculous cholecystitis include
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Acute inflammation of the gallbladder can occur without gallstones. Acalculous cholecystitis typically develops in critically ill patients in the intensive care unit. Patients on parenteral nutrition with extensive burns, sepsis, major operations, multiple trauma, or prolonged illness with multiple organ system failure are at risk for developing acalculous cholecystitis. The cause is unknown, but gallbladder distention with bile stasis and ischemia has been implicated as causative actors. Pathologic examination of the gallbladder wall reveals oedema of the serosa and muscular layers, with patchy thrombosis of arterioles and venules. USG is the diagnostic test of choice. Percutaneous USG or CT -guided cholecystostomy is typically the intervention of choice, as they are often unfit for surgery. After recovery from the systemic disease, cholecystectomy may be indicated.

questions.text: The most common type of gallbladder cancer is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Between 80 and 90% of the gallbladder tumors are adenocarcinomas. Squamous cell, adenosquamous, oat cell, and other anaplastic lesions occur rarely.

questions.text: Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses are seen with
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses are associated with chronic cholecystitis. Chroniccholecystitis is the histopathologic result of multiple bouts of symptomatic cholelithiasis or biliary colic. On pathologic examination, Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses develop as a result of atrophy of the mucosa. As the mucosa atrophies, the epithelium protrudes into the muscle coat, leading to the formation of these sinuses.

questions.text: The initial test or a suspected postoperative bile leak includes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Bile leak, most commonly from the cystic duct stump, a transected aberrant right hepatic duct, or a lateral injury to the main bile duct, usually presents with pain, fever, and a mild elevation of liver function tests. A CT scan or an ultrasound will show either a collection (bilioma) in the gallbladder area or free fluid (bile) in the peritoneum.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with unresectable cholangiocarcinoma undergoing palliative therapy presents with fever, right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and cough for 1 day. Temperature was 101.7°F, pulse 93 beats/min, blood pressure 112/65 mmHg, respiratory rate 20 breaths/min, and saturation 98% on room air. Physical examination shows a soft and non distended abdomen with tenderness in the right upper quadrant and hepatomegaly. Lab results include a white blood cell count of 14,000/mm3 and alkaline phosphatase level of 215 IU/L. Chest x-ray shows an elevated right hemi-diaphragm and right lower lobe atelectasis. Ultrasound is performed showing a round hypoechoic lesion within the liver, with well-defined borders and several internal echoes, mildly dilated intrahepatic bile ducts, and no cholelithiasis or pericholecystic fluid. In addition to further imaging, what is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Liver abscesses classically present as fever, right upper quadrant pain, nausea, pleuritic chest pain, cough or dyspnea, and sometimes with sepsis. They may be pyogenic (bacterial), amebic, or fungal. Pyogenic abscess is usually polymicrobial, although common microbes include Escherichia coli or other gram negative bacteria, Streptococcus species, and anaerobes such as Bacteroides. Patient risk factors include underlying biliary cancer, recent ablative liver therapy, or liver transplantation. Today, the most frequent source of pyogenic abscess is a contiguous infection in the biliary tract, such as cholangitis. Other sources include infectious foci within the portal venous drainage system, direct extension from perihepatic sites, and hematogenous spread. The right lobe is the most commonly involved, which has been attributed to a streaming effect of the portal vein. Approximately 20% of pyogenic abscesses are cryptogenic. The diagnosis is based on the clinical findings and hepatic imaging and may be confirmed by fine-needle aspiration. While ultrasound is a good modality to visualize the liver abscess, gallbladder, and intrahepatic bile ducts, computed tomography (CT) is more sensitive and further allows for evaluation of another underlying cause such as a biliary tree cancer. Treatment of pyogenic abscess requires eradication of both the abscess and the source. Treatment of the abscess usually requires drainage by operative or percutaneous approaches. Antibiotic therapy alone may suffice for the treatment of multiple small abscesses.

choices.text: Laparoscopic resection of the gallbladder fossa
Open extended cholecystectomy including segment 4b and 5 liver resection as well as removal of porta hepatis lymph nodes
CBD excision to achieve negative margins with Roux-en- Y hepaticojejunostomy reconstruction

questions.text: A 63-y/o female undergoes a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. The pathology report states that there is a foci of carcinoma which invades, but does not penetrate through the lamina propria. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gallbladder cancer is an aggressive malignancy that is often asymptomatic until it reaches an advanced stage. This is an early-stage T1a tumor that was found incidentally. The treatment is cholecystectomy alone because the tumor is limited to the lamina propria and the chance of lymph node disease is less than 3%

questions.text: A 40-y/o man is evaluated for fluctuating jaundice, pruritus, and fatigue. Liver enzyme levels demonstrate cholestasis. Ultrasound imaging does not show gallstones or bile duct dilation. What diagnostic test should be obtained next?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The findings described are fairly typical of sclerosing cholangitis, which can also be discovered in asymptomatic patients based on a cholestatic liver enzyme pattern. Sclerosing cholangitis is a disease of undetermined cause characterized by inflammatory fibrosis and stenosis of the bile ducts. Primary sclerosing cholangitis may be an isolated finding or may occur in conjunction with a variety of other disease processes, most commonly ulcerative colitis.. Although the cause of primary sclerosing cholangitis is unknown, most attention has focused on an autoimmune or infectious cause. Antimitochondrial antibodies are generally associated with primary biliary cirrhosis but they can be seen in PSC also. The diagnosis is usually made following ERCP showing multiple strictures and dilations, which give a “beaded” appearance to the ducts. Typically, sclerosing cholangitis is a diffuse process that affects both the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.

choices.text: Observation, since there is no evidence of choledocholithiasis
Complete surgical excision of the dilated bile duct segment and reconstruction with a hepaticojejunostomy

questions.text: A 22-y/o female presents to the emergency room with RUQ pain and jaundice. Ultrasound shows a normal appearing gallbladder without stones, but a diffusely dilated CBD. Follow-up ERCP confirms a diffusely dilated fusiform extrahepatic bile duct without filling defects, and normal-appearing intrahepatic biliary anatomy. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Choledochal cysts are a rare cause of RUQ pain and jaundice. They are premalignant lesions, carrying a 10%–30% risk of carcinoma, so observation is not appropriate. The most accepted theory of their pathogenesis is related to an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction, which allows pancreatic fluid to reflux up into the biliary tract. This results in chronic inflammation and cystic degeneration of the bile duct. This patient has a type I cyst, which involves fusiform dilatation of the extrahepatic biliary tree and is treated by complete excision and hepaticojejunostomy reconstruction. Type II cysts appear as a diverticulum off the CBD and are treated by excision, as well as biliary-enteric drainage if an anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction is present. Type III cysts, also known as choledochoceles, appear as intramural CBD cystic dilatation within the duodenal wall. Their pathogenesis is not clear and so treatment is directed at relieving the biliary or duodenal obstruction (if present). This can be approached via a transduodenal excision or endoscopic sphincteroplasty. Type IV disease involves both the intra- and extrahepatic biliary trees. Treatment depends on the anatomic pattern of disease. Type V disease, also known as Caroli disease, involves only the intrahepatic bile ducts. Surgical treatment ranges from liver resection to transplantation depending on the extent of ductal involvement

choices.text: IV fluids resuscitation and antibiotics, and biliary drainage if no response to treatment in 24 h
IV fluids resuscitation, antibiotics, and urgent biliary drainage

questions.text: A 38-y/o male presents to the emergency department with fevers and RUQ pain. His temperature is 39°C, he is tachycardic to 110/min and the remainder of his vitals are normal. On abdominal examination, he has a positive Murphy’s sign. Laboratory values are significant for a WBC count of 15,000/mm3 and a total bilirubin of 5.5 mg/dL. Ultrasound shows a thickened gallbladder wall, stones, pericholecystic fluid, and a CBD diameter of 8 mm. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) The three diagnostic criteria for acute cholangitis are (A) signs of systemic inflammation (e.g., fever, abnormal WBC, increased CRP), (B) cholestasis, and (C) imaging suggestive of biliary dilatation and/or etiology of obstruction (stricture, stone, etc.). A patient has a suspected diagnosis of cholangitis if he or she has one item in A and one item in either B or C. A patient has a definite diagnosis of cholangitis if he or she has one item from A, B, AND C. The guidelines stratify patients into severity grades, which allow recommendations for management. Grade III (severe) acute cholangitis is associated with organ dysfunction with any of the following signs: hypotension, altered mental status, PaO2/FiO2 < 300, oliguria or serum creatinine > 2 mg/dL, INR > 1.5, or platelet count < 100,000/mm3. Grade II (moderate) acute cholangitis is associated with any two of the following conditions: abnormal WBC count (>12,000/mm3, <4000/ mm3), fever,39°C, age> 75 years old, total bilirubin > 5 mg/dL, or hypoalbuminemia (lower limit of normal × 0.7). Grade I (mild) acute cholangitis does not meet the criteria of grade II or III. Initial treatment for all grades includes IV fluid resuscitation and initiation of antimicrobials. For grade I (mild), when no response to the initial treatment is observed within 24 h, biliary tract drainage is recommended. For grade II (moderate), biliary tract drainage is immediately performed, in conjunction with IV fluids and antibiotics. For grade III (severe), after IV fluid resuscitation with antibiotics, organ system supportive care takes priority (positive pressure ventilation, vasopressors, etc.) and biliary tract drainage is recommended when safe to do so. Treatment for the etiology of acute cholangitis (e.g., cholecystectomy for gallstones) is considered once acute illness has resolved.

choices.text: Normal expected decline after relief of any obstructive Jaundice

questions.text: Two weeks following hepaticojejunostomy for the treatment of a benign bile duct stricture, a patient has a serum bilirubin level of 6 mg/dL. The patient was jaundiced for 4 weeks before the operation and had a preoperative serum bilirubin level of 12 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this current serum bilirubin level?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) After relief of biliary obstruction, there is a prompt increase in bile flow, and normal bile acid secretion resumes within several days. Serum bilirubin levels decline approximately 50% by 36 to 48 h after surgery and 8% per day thereafter. This rate varies depending on the duration of the jaundice. Delta-bilirubin is a form of bilirubin that is covalently bonded to albumin and is measured as part of the direct bilirubin fraction. As such, it is not filtered by the kidneys and has the same serum half-life as albumin, approximately 18 days, which accounts for the slow decline in serum bilirubin levels observed in patients following relief of longstanding jaundice.

choices.text: Hospital stay is shorter for the LCBDE group.
Cost is greater for the ERCP followed by the LCBDE group.
There are fewer retained stones after the laparoscopic common bile duct exploration (LCBDE) group.

questions.text: A 35-y/o female presents with choledocholithiasis. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy with biliary clearance is recommended. Which of the following is FALSE regarding laparoscopic CBD exploration (LCBDE) versus preoperative ERCP followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) The ideal method of treating choledocholithiasis is controversial. The two-stage approach involves a preoperative ERCP for the CBD clearance followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy. The alternative one-stage procedure is laparoscopic cholecystectomy with LCBDE. The morbidity and mortality rates are equivalent between the two groups. The CBD clearance rates are also equivalent, both around 90%. The one-stage approach is more cost effective, and the overall hospital stay for the patient is shorter. However, the operative time is longer for the one-stage approach. There is no significant difference in rates of retained stones between the two groups (both 8%–15%).

choices.text: Observation as a persistent fistula is expected after a subtotal fenestrating cholecystectomy
Make her nil per oral and start TPN

questions.text: A 71-y/o female presents to your office for a persistent high-output biliary fistula 3 weeks after you performed a subtotal fenestrating cholecystectomy with subhepatic Jackson Pratt (JP) drain placement for acute cholecystitis. She is asymptomatic. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A bile leak is not uncommon following subtotal cholecystectomy, especially of the fenestrated type, but most is self-limited and will close without any intervention. A persistent bile leak after a subtotal fenestrating cholecystectomy should raise concern for a distal biliary obstruction. In this case, the most likely etiology would be a retained stone. Therefore an ERCP would be both diagnostic and therapeutic. There is no role for TPN or octreotide or reoperation in this patient

questions.text: A 26-y/o female who is 10 weeks pregnant presents to your office with symptomatic cholelithiasis. She has had two recent trips to the emergency room for significant pain. Her ultrasound from her most recent visit demonstrates a wall of 3 mm, no pericholecystic fluid, an impacted stone in the neck of the gallbladder, and a CBD of 4 mm. On examination, she has mild RUQ pain but no Murphy’s sign. The most appropriate management is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Symptomatic gallstone disease is second to appendicitis as the most common nonobstetric surgical problem that affects pregnant women. The overwhelming majority of women who become symptomatic during the first trimester of pregnancy will have continuing or recurrent symptoms before delivery. Without definitive treatment, rehospitalizations are frequent and there is an ongoing risk to both the mother and the fetus. Most propose that the second trimester is the ideal time to operate. This avoids the risk of spontaneous miscarriage and the theoretic concern of teratogenicity in the first trimester, while also avoiding the risk of preterm birth in the third trimester. That being said, laparoscopic cholecystectomy has been performed successfully during all stages of pregnancy. In late term, however, the size of the gravid uterus interferes with trocar placement. For this reason, many surgeons prefer an open approach if surgery is necessary during the third trimester.

questions.text: A 46-y/o male presents with 2 days of RUQ pain. His labs are significant for a WBC count of 15,000/mm3. His ultrasound notes numerous gallstones with wall thickening and pericholecystic fluid. On examination, his temperature is 99.5°F, and he has a positive Murphy’s sign. What is the best management for this individual?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The former debate over early versus late cholecystectomy for acute cholecystitis has been put to rest. Prospective studies have demonstrated that early cholecystectomy within the first few days is not associated with higher morbidity or mortality and that delayed surgery requires longer hospitalization, is more expensive, and risks recurrent biliary problems before definitive therapy. Most patients are treated effectively by stabilization and prompt surgery. From a technical standpoint, cholecystectomy is often easier during the first day or two of the patient’s illness when the inflammation tends to be more edematous rather than necrotic and hyperemic, as it becomes when the process progresses. Most advocate cholecystectomy within the first 72 h, while others push this to within the first 96 h. Laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred treatment in most circumstances, with decreased length of stay and morbidity compared with open cholecystectomy. However, conversion to an open procedure is required more often than when the procedure is performed electively for nonacute symptoms.

questions.text: A 99mTc-iminodiacetic acid scan in a fasting patient demonstrates the following: normal liver activity, no gallbladder visualization at 60 min, intestinal activity present at 60 min, and gallbladder visualization at 120 min. These findings are most consistent with which of the following situations?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) After IV injection, these radioisotopes are taken up by the liver and excreted into the biliary tract. The characteristics of a normal study include visualization of the gallbladder within 60 min in fasting patients and the appearance of radioisotope in the duodenum by about the same time. In nonfasting patients, visualization of the gallbladder may be delayed. With both calculous and acalculous acute cholecystitis, the gallbladder is not visualized because of cystic duct obstruction. No visualization or delayed visualization is common with chronic cholecystitis.

choices.text: 270º abutment of the superior mesenteric artery
Tumor located in the neck of the pancreas
Inability to verify malignancy histologically before resection
90º abutment of the superior mesenteric vein

questions.text: A jaundiced, otherwise healthy patient is noted to have a 3-cm mass in the head of the pancreas on CT. EUS-guided fine-needle aspiration shows cancer. The mass abuts the portal vein, but there is no clear evidence of vessel involvement or metastatic disease. You proceed to the operating room. Intraoperatively, you are concerned about the respectability of the tumor. In which of the following situations is resection contraindicated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Criteria for unresectability are:- 1.celiac artery involvement 2.SMA involvement 3.ascites 4.>180` abutment to SMA

choices.text: Urgent (within 24 h) cholecystectomy and common bile duct exploration
Urgent ERCP and subsequent laparoscopic cholecystectomy
Initial supportive therapy with cholecystectomy performed during the same admission
Initial supportive therapy with cholecystectomy performed in 6 to 8 weeks

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to the ED with RUQ pain and epigastric pain and associated emesis. Lab results are significant for a total bilirubin of 1.9 g/dL, WBC of 11,500 cells per MCL, and lipase level of 300 U/L, and AST/ALT are mildly elevated. An USG is performed showing a duct of 6 mm and numerous mobile stones in the gallbladder. Acute gallstone pancreatitis is diagnosed. Which of the following is considered standard treatment?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Cholecystectomy is indicated because gallstone pancreatitis is a recurrent problem in 30%–50% of patients if surgery is not performed. Most surgeons advise initial nonoperative therapy until the patient’s signs and symptoms subside (most do within 2 to 3 days), followed by elective cholecystectomy with intraoperative imaging of the common bile duct by cholangiography or intraoperative ultrasonography during the same hospitalization.

questions.text: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of persistent jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine since the second week of life. On examination, the infant has hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show the following: • Serum total bilirubin: 12 mg/dL (direct bilirubin: 8 mg/dL) • Liver enzymes: Elevated AST and ALT • Gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT): Significantly elevated An ultrasound of the abdomen shows an absent gallbladder. A percutaneous liver biopsy demonstrates bile duct proliferation, portal fibrosis, and inflammation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Biliary atresia o Persistent jaundice beyond 2 weeks with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is highly suggestive of cholestasis. o The combination of pale stools, dark urine, absent gallbladder on imaging, and findings of bile duct proliferation on biopsy are classic for biliary atresia. o Early diagnosis and surgical intervention (Kasai portoenterostomy) are crucial to improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 4-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice, acholic stools, and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations show direct hyperbilirubinemia and elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). A hepatobiliary scintigraphy scan shows no excretion of radiotracer into the bowel even after 24 hours. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Perform percutaneous liver biopsy • Hepatobiliary scintigraphy supports biliary obstruction, but liver biopsy is crucial for confirming biliary atresia. • Biopsy findings (bile duct proliferation, portal fibrosis) guide the diagnosis before surgical intervention (Kasai procedure).

choices.text: Oral dissolution therapy with ursodeoxycholic acid

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with recurrent episodes of upper abdominal pain radiating to the back, associated with nausea and vomiting. Ultrasound shows multiple gallstones without signs of gallbladder wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laparoscopic cholecystectomy Symptomatic gallstone disease is an indication for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, even in the absence of complications such as cholecystitis or biliary obstruction.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a relative contraindication for laparoscopic cholecystectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Severe cardiopulmonary disease Pneumoperitoneum during laparoscopic surgery can exacerbate cardiopulmonary conditions, making it a relative contraindication.

choices.text: Reduced incidence of bile duct injury

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT an advantage of laparoscopic cholecystectomy compared to open cholecystectomy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Reduced incidence of bile duct injury The incidence of bile duct injury is slightly higher in laparoscopic cholecystectomy compared to open cholecystectomy, particularly in challenging cases.

choices.text: Blindly clip and cut the suspected cystic duct and artery

questions.text: During laparoscopic cholecystectomy for a difficult gallbladder with severe inflammation and dense adhesions, the surgeon is unable to safely identify the cystic duct and artery. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Perform subtotal cholecystectomy Subtotal cholecystectomy is a safe option in cases of severe inflammation where the critical view of safety cannot be achieved.

choices.text: Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and cystic artery
Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and inferior border of the liver
Cystic duct, right hepatic artery, and inferior border of the liver
Common bile duct, cystic duct, and superior border of the pancreas

questions.text: A surgeon is performing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy and needs to identify the boundaries of Calot's Triangle. Which of the following structures define the boundaries of Calot's Triangle?
questions.solution: Correct Answer A. Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and cystic artery This is the original and anatomically correct definition of Calot’s Triangle, as described by Jean-François Calot in 1891. The triangle is bounded by: • Medially: Common hepatic duct • Laterally: Cystic duct • Superiorly: Cystic artery It is a small anatomical triangle in the right upper abdomen, and its main surgical relevance is that the cystic artery lies within it and must be carefully identified and ligated during gallbladder surgery (cholecystectomy). Option B: Common hepatic duct, cystic duct, and inferior border of the liver This describes the hepatocystic triangle, which is used in modern surgical practice to guide safe dissection. Its boundaries are: • Common hepatic duct • Cystic duct • Inferior surface of the liver Many textbooks and surgeons casually refer to this as "Calot’s triangle," but this is not anatomically accurate. In exams or when precision is required, this is not the correct definition of Calot’s triangle. Option C: Cystic duct, right hepatic artery, and inferior border of the liver This is not an accepted anatomical triangle. The right hepatic artery is closely related to the area but is not a boundary of Calot’s triangle. Including it can cause misunderstanding and increases the risk of vascular injury during surgery. Option D: Common bile duct, cystic duct, and superior border of the pancreas This is anatomically incorrect. The pancreas lies far below the gallbladder and Calot’s triangle, and does not form any part of the triangle's boundaries. This option combines unrelated anatomical structures. There is often confusion between Calot’s Triangle and the hepatocystic triangle because many modern surgical references and textbooks informally use the term "Calot’s Triangle" to refer to the hepatocystic triangle. However, anatomically and in exams that test strict definitions, Calot’s Triangle includes the cystic artery as the superior boundary, not the liver. So while both triangles are clinically important, only option A describes the true Calot’s Triangle.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and fever. Imaging reveals a gallstone in the cystic duct compressing the common hepatic duct, leading to obstruction which is shown below. Which of the following best describes this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mirizzi Syndrome Mirizzi Syndrome is characterized by a gallstone impacted in the cystic duct or Hartmann’s pouch of the gallbladder causing external compression of the common hepatic duct, leading to obstructive jaundice. Key features of Mirizzi Syndrome: • Symptoms: Jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, fever • Imaging findings: Dilated biliary tree, gallstone compressing the hepatic duct • Complications: May progress to fistula formation between the gallbladder and the bile duct.

questions.text: A patient with Mirizzi Syndrome is suspected to have a cholecystocholedochal fistula. According to the Csendes classification, what is the most appropriate imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) MRCP is the most appropriate imaging modality for evaluating Mirizzi Syndrome, especially for detecting fistulas or bile duct involvement. It is non-invasive and provides detailed views of the biliary tree and surrounding structures.
